title: Personal Safety and Protective Behaviours
subject: Health and Physical Education
substrand: Safety, Risk Management and Protective Behaviours
description: This topic explores personal safety strategies, recognising warning signs, protective behaviours, body safety, and responding to unsafe situations. Students develop skills to protect themselves and seek help when needed.
curriculumDescriptions: Plan, rehearse and evaluate strategies for managing situations where their own or others' safety may be at risk
Investigate and select strategies to promote health, safety and wellbeing

A.title: Personal Safety and Protective Behaviours - Foundation
A.levelDescription: Students working 2-3 years below the expected level will focus on basic body safety concepts, recognising safe and unsafe feelings, and knowing trusted adults who can help.
A.contentAdaptations: Uses simple language, visual supports, concrete examples, and clear safety rules. Focuses on body ownership, recognising feelings, and telling trusted adults.
learningIntentions: I am learning that my body belongs to me
I am learning to recognise safe and unsafe feelings
I am learning who I can tell if something makes me feel unsafe
successCriteria: I can say that my body belongs to me
I can tell when I have an unsafe feeling
I can name trusted adults I can talk to
prerequisites: Knowledge of familiar adults in their life

vocabularyTerms.definition: Knowing that your body belongs to you and keeping it safe
Parts of your body covered by underwear or bathers
A feeling that tells you everything is okay
A feeling that tells you something is wrong or scary
A grown-up you can go to for help and who keeps you safe
Something you don't tell other people
A secret that makes you happy, like a surprise birthday party
A secret that makes you feel worried, scared or confused

contentSections.title: My Body Belongs to Me
contentSections.content: Your body belongs to you. This is very important. No one has the right to touch your body in a way that makes you feel uncomfortable. You have private parts - these are the parts of your body covered by underwear or bathers. Private parts are private because they are special and just for you. It's okay for doctors or nurses to check these parts if a parent or carer is there and has said it's okay.

contentSections.title: Safe and Unsafe Feelings
contentSections.content: Your body can tell you when something is safe or unsafe. Safe feelings might be warm, relaxed, and happy - like when you're playing with friends or getting a hug from someone you love. Unsafe feelings might be scared, worried, confused, or sick in your tummy. These feelings are like alarm bells that tell you something might be wrong. Always listen to your body's feelings - they help keep you safe.

contentSections.title: Safe and Unsafe Secrets
contentSections.content: Some secrets are safe and some are unsafe. A safe secret makes you feel happy - like a surprise present for someone. Safe secrets usually don't last very long and are fun. An unsafe secret makes you feel worried, scared, or confused. If someone asks you to keep a secret that gives you an unsafe feeling, you should tell a trusted adult. It's never wrong to tell an unsafe secret.

contentSections.title: Trusted Adults
contentSections.content: A trusted adult is a grown-up who listens to you, believes you, and helps keep you safe. You might have several trusted adults in your life - like parents, grandparents, teachers, or school counsellors. If something makes you feel unsafe, you should tell a trusted adult. If the first adult you tell doesn't help, keep telling until someone does help. Trusted adults want to keep you safe.

options.text: Parts of your body covered by underwear or bathers
options.feedback: Correct! Private parts are the parts of your body covered by underwear or bathers.

options.text: Your hands and feet
options.feedback: Hands and feet are not private parts - they are not covered by underwear.

options.text: Your favourite toys
options.feedback: Private parts refers to parts of your body, not objects.

options.text: Your bedroom
options.feedback: Private parts refers to parts of your body, not places.

understand.question: Why should you listen to unsafe feelings in your body?

options.text: Because feelings are always wrong
options.feedback: Actually, your feelings are often right and can help protect you.

options.text: Because unsafe feelings are like alarm bells that tell you something might be wrong
options.feedback: Correct! Unsafe feelings help warn you when something isn't right.

options.text: Because adults don't understand feelings
options.feedback: Trusted adults do understand feelings and want to help when you feel unsafe.

options.text: Because feelings go away if you ignore them
options.feedback: It's important not to ignore unsafe feelings - they're trying to protect you.

apply.question: Someone asks you to keep a secret that makes you feel scared and worried. What should you do?

options.text: Keep the secret because you promised
options.feedback: You should never have to keep a secret that makes you feel scared or worried.

options.text: Tell a trusted adult even though it feels hard
options.feedback: Correct! Unsafe secrets should always be told to a trusted adult.

options.text: Try to forget about it
options.feedback: Trying to forget doesn't help. A trusted adult can help you with scary secrets.

options.text: Only tell your friends
options.feedback: Friends your own age may not be able to help. You need a trusted adult.

analyse.question: What is the difference between a safe secret and an unsafe secret? Give an example of each.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students should explain that safe secrets make you feel happy and usually don't last long (like a surprise party), while unsafe secrets make you feel scared, worried, or confused. They should give an example of each type.
successCriteria: Explains that safe secrets feel happy
Explains that unsafe secrets feel scary or worried
Gives an appropriate example of a safe secret
Gives an appropriate example of an unsafe secret

evaluate.question: A friend says 'You should always keep a promise to keep a secret no matter what.' Do you agree? Explain why or why not.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students should disagree with this statement and explain that unsafe secrets should be told to a trusted adult. They should understand that keeping them safe is more important than keeping a promise about a secret that makes them feel bad.
successCriteria: Disagrees with the statement
Explains that unsafe secrets should be told
Shows understanding that safety is more important than promises about scary secrets

create.question: Draw or write about your three trusted adults. Include who they are and why you trust them.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students identify three trusted adults in their life and explain why they trust each one. Reasons might include: they listen, they believe me, they keep me safe, they help me with problems.
successCriteria: Identifies three appropriate trusted adults
Gives a reason for trusting each one
Reasons relate to safety, listening, or helping

unistructural.stem: Who can you tell if something makes you feel unsafe?
unistructural.modelResponse: I can tell a trusted adult like my mum or teacher.
unistructural.rubric: Names an appropriate trusted adult such as parent, carer, teacher, or family member.

multistructural.stem: List three things your body might feel when you have an unsafe feeling.
multistructural.modelResponse: Three things my body might feel when I have an unsafe feeling are: 1) A sick feeling in my tummy, 2) My heart beating fast, 3) Wanting to run away or hide.
multistructural.rubric: Lists three physical sensations associated with unsafe feelings. May include tummy feelings, heart racing, sweating, shaking, wanting to run away, or similar.

relational.stem: Explain why 'my body belongs to me' is an important idea for keeping safe.
relational.modelResponse: The idea that 'my body belongs to me' is important because it means I get to decide about my body. If someone tries to touch me in a way I don't like, I can say no because it's my body. It also means I can tell a trusted adult if someone touches me in a way that feels wrong. Knowing my body is mine helps me understand that no one should hurt me or touch my private parts without permission.
relational.rubric: Explains how body ownership connects to the right to say no. Shows understanding that this concept supports seeking help. May mention private parts or unwanted touching.

extendedAbstract.stem: Think about why some children might find it hard to tell a trusted adult about unsafe secrets. What could help make it easier?
extendedAbstract.modelResponse: Some children might find it hard to tell about unsafe secrets for many reasons. They might be scared the person who told them the secret will be angry. They might feel like they did something wrong or will get in trouble. They might worry that adults won't believe them. They might not have words to explain what happened. Things that could help include: adults telling children they will always listen and believe them, teaching children the words to use, explaining that telling about unsafe secrets is the right thing to do, and having many trusted adults so there are options to tell.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Identifies multiple reasons children might not disclose. Suggests practical ways to make disclosure easier. Shows empathetic understanding of barriers to telling.

reflectionQuestions: What does your body feel like when you have a safe feeling?
What would you do if someone asked you to keep an unsafe secret?
selfAssessment: I know that my body belongs to me
I can recognise safe and unsafe feelings
I know trusted adults I can talk to
studentReflection.connectionToLife: Knowing that your body belongs to you and that you can tell trusted adults about problems helps keep you safe. These skills will help you throughout your life.

B.title: Personal Safety and Protective Behaviours - Developing
B.levelDescription: Students working 1 year below the expected level will explore personal safety strategies, recognise warning signs, understand body safety concepts, and practise responses to unsafe situations.
B.contentAdaptations: Uses clear language with definitions, scenarios from everyday life, and opportunities to practise responses. Builds on basic concepts to develop practical safety skills.
learningIntentions: I am learning to recognise warning signs in situations
I am learning personal safety strategies
I am learning how to respond to unsafe situations
successCriteria: I can identify warning signs that a situation might be unsafe
I can describe personal safety strategies I can use
I can explain what to do in different unsafe situations
prerequisites: Ability to identify safe and unsafe feelings

vocabularyTerms.definition: Something that tells you a situation might become unsafe
Actions you take to protect yourself from harm
A limit that shows where one thing ends and another begins
The area around your body that feels comfortable for you
Speaking up for yourself in a clear and confident way
Your right to control what happens to your body
When someone offers you something to get you to do what they want
When someone says something bad will happen if you don't do what they want

contentSections.title: Recognising Warning Signs
contentSections.content: Warning signs tell us a situation might become unsafe. Some warning signs come from people's behaviour: someone being too friendly too fast, asking you to keep secrets, wanting to be alone with you, offering special treats or gifts for no reason, or touching you when you don't want them to. Other warning signs come from situations: being in an isolated place, feeling pressured, or something just 'feeling wrong'. Learning to notice warning signs helps you act early to stay safe.

contentSections.title: Personal Boundaries
contentSections.content: Boundaries are limits that help keep you safe. Personal space is one kind of boundary - the area around your body where you feel comfortable. Different people and situations have different boundary needs. You have the right to set boundaries about who can touch you and how. You can say 'No' or 'Stop' when someone crosses your boundaries. Respecting other people's boundaries is just as important as having your own respected.

contentSections.title: Being Assertive
contentSections.content: Being assertive means speaking up for yourself in a clear, confident way. When you feel unsafe, you can use assertive words like 'No', 'Stop', 'Don't touch me', or 'I don't like that'. Stand up straight and use a strong voice. You don't have to be polite to someone who is making you feel unsafe. If words don't work, you can leave the situation and get help from a trusted adult.

contentSections.title: Responding to Unsafe Situations
contentSections.content: When you're in an unsafe situation, there are steps you can take. First, say 'No' clearly if someone is crossing your boundaries. If possible, leave the situation - go to where there are other people. Then tell a trusted adult what happened as soon as you can. Remember, it's never your fault if someone acts unsafely toward you. The person who did the wrong thing is responsible, not you.

options.text: A fence around your house
options.feedback: Personal boundaries are about your body and space, not physical fences.

options.text: A limit that helps keep you safe, like who can touch you and how
options.feedback: Correct! Personal boundaries are limits about your body, space, and what you're comfortable with.

options.text: A rule you have to follow at school
options.feedback: School rules are different from personal boundaries, which are about your own body and space.

options.text: The edge of a sports field
options.feedback: Personal boundaries are about you, not physical areas.

understand.question: Why might someone who wants to harm you give you special gifts or treats?

options.text: Because they are just being nice
options.feedback: While gifts are sometimes just nice, unexpected gifts from someone who then crosses boundaries is a warning sign.

options.text: To make you feel you owe them something or to gain your trust
options.feedback: Correct! This is called a 'bribe' and is a warning sign - it can be used to manipulate you.

options.text: Because they forgot your birthday
options.feedback: Birthday gifts from safe people are normal, but unexpected gifts that come with requests for secrets are a warning sign.

options.text: Because all adults give children gifts
options.feedback: Not all adults give gifts, and gifts used to manipulate children are a warning sign.

apply.question: Someone you know is standing too close to you and it makes you uncomfortable. What is an assertive response?

options.text: Say nothing because it might be rude to ask them to move
options.feedback: You don't have to put up with feeling uncomfortable. It's okay to speak up about your personal space.

options.text: Step back and say 'Please give me some space - you're standing too close'
options.feedback: Correct! This is assertive - you're clearly stating what you need while being respectful.

options.text: Push them away without saying anything
options.feedback: Using words first is better than physical action. Try being assertive with words first.

options.text: Just move away quietly and hope they don't follow
options.feedback: While moving away is okay, being assertive helps the person understand your boundary.

analyse.question: Compare these two situations. Which one shows more warning signs and why? Situation A: A family friend gives you a birthday present at your party. Situation B: An older person you don't know well gives you presents often, asks to spend time alone with you, and asks you to keep it secret.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students should identify Situation B as showing more warning signs. They should analyse the specific warning signs: unusual gift-giving, wanting to be alone, asking for secrecy. They should explain why Situation A is normal (expected context, open situation) while Situation B has multiple concerning elements.
successCriteria: Correctly identifies Situation B as concerning
Lists specific warning signs present in Situation B
Explains why Situation A is normal and appropriate
Shows understanding of what makes situations concerning

evaluate.question: Some people say children should always obey adults without question. Evaluate this idea in terms of personal safety.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students should evaluate this critically. While respecting adults is generally good, blind obedience can be unsafe. Children need to know they can say no to adults who cross boundaries, that not all adults are safe, and that speaking up is allowed when feeling unsafe. Strong responses balance respect for adults with understanding that safety comes first.
successCriteria: Recognises problems with blind obedience
Explains that some adults may not be safe
Acknowledges that children can say no for safety
Balances respect for adults with safety needs

create.question: Create a safety plan for what you would do if you found yourself in an unsafe situation. Include what you would say, what you would do, and who you would tell.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students create a practical safety plan with: assertive statements they could use ('No', 'Stop', 'I don't like this'), actions to take (leave if possible, find safe people or places), and trusted adults to tell. Plan should be realistic and personally meaningful.
successCriteria: Includes assertive words or phrases to use
Describes actions to take (leaving, finding help)
Names specific trusted adults to tell
Plan is realistic and practical

unistructural.stem: Name one warning sign that a situation might be unsafe.
unistructural.modelResponse: One warning sign is when someone asks you to keep secrets from your parents.
unistructural.rubric: Names one appropriate warning sign such as secret-keeping requests, isolation attempts, bribery, or inappropriate touching.

multistructural.stem: List four steps you could take if you found yourself in an unsafe situation.
multistructural.modelResponse: Four steps I could take are: 1) Say 'No' or 'Stop' in a strong voice, 2) Try to leave and go to where there are other people, 3) Tell a trusted adult what happened, 4) Keep telling until someone helps me.
multistructural.rubric: Lists four appropriate steps. May include saying no, leaving, seeking help, telling adults, and persisting until helped.

relational.stem: Explain how being assertive and knowing your trusted adults work together to keep you safe.
relational.modelResponse: Being assertive and knowing trusted adults work together for safety. First, being assertive helps in the moment - saying 'No' or 'Stop' might stop the unsafe behaviour right away. But sometimes that's not enough, and you need backup. That's where trusted adults come in - they can step in to protect you and make sure the unsafe situation doesn't happen again. Knowing who your trusted adults are means you can get to help faster. And trusted adults can also help you practise being assertive so you're more prepared. Both skills support each other.
relational.rubric: Explains how assertiveness helps in the moment. Shows how trusted adults provide backup and ongoing protection. Demonstrates understanding that both skills work together for comprehensive safety.

extendedAbstract.stem: Consider why people who want to harm children often use bribes and threats. How does understanding this help you stay safer?
extendedAbstract.modelResponse: People who want to harm children use bribes and threats as strategies to control them. Bribes (special treats, gifts, attention) make children feel special and create a sense of owing something back. They build trust and make children less likely to question or tell. Threats (scary consequences if you tell) use fear to keep children silent. Understanding these tactics helps in several ways: you can recognise them as warning signs before harm happens, you know that feeling confused by 'nice' behaviour plus uncomfortable feelings is a warning, you understand that threats are used because the person knows they're doing wrong, and you realise that telling a trusted adult breaks the power of both tactics.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Analyses why these tactics are used (control, manipulation). Explains how understanding helps with recognition and response. Shows sophisticated understanding of manipulation dynamics and how awareness provides protection.

reflectionQuestions: What are some warning signs you now know to look out for?
How does it feel to practise being assertive?
Who would you tell if something made you feel unsafe?
selfAssessment: I can identify warning signs in situations
I can describe personal safety strategies
I know what to do in unsafe situations
studentReflection.connectionToLife: Knowing warning signs and safety strategies helps you trust your instincts and take action when needed. These skills protect you now and will be useful throughout your life.

C.title: Personal Safety and Protective Behaviours - Standard
C.levelDescription: Students working at the expected level will analyse personal safety strategies, evaluate responses to unsafe situations, plan and rehearse protective behaviours, and understand the dynamics of unsafe situations.
C.contentAdaptations: Uses curriculum-appropriate language with relevant scenarios for adolescents. Encourages critical analysis of situations and development of personal safety plans.
learningIntentions: I am learning to analyse different types of unsafe situations and appropriate responses
I am learning to plan and rehearse protective behaviours
I am learning to understand the dynamics of grooming and manipulation
successCriteria: I can analyse situations to identify safety risks and appropriate responses
I can plan and practise protective behaviours for various scenarios
I can explain grooming tactics and how to recognise them

Awareness of trusted adults and help-seeking

vocabularyTerms.definition: The process by which someone builds trust and emotional connection with a young person in order to manipulate or abuse them
Using pressure, threats, or force to make someone do something they don't want to do
Controlling or influencing someone in a sneaky or unfair way
Telling someone about an experience, especially when seeking help
A group of trusted people you can turn to for help with safety concerns
Actions or words used to calm down a tense or potentially dangerous situation
Being aware of what is happening around you and potential risks in your environment
When one person has more power or control than another in a relationship or situation

contentSections.title: Understanding Grooming
contentSections.content: Grooming is a process where someone builds trust and connection with a young person in order to exploit them. Groomers often target vulnerability, offer special attention or gifts, gradually push boundaries, create secrecy, and isolate the young person from their support network. Grooming can happen in person or online. It often feels confusing because the person seems nice and caring. Recognising grooming tactics - excessive flattery, boundary-pushing, secrets, isolation - helps you identify concerning situations early. Anyone can be targeted by grooming; it's never the young person's fault.

contentSections.title: Planning Protective Responses
contentSections.content: Planning ahead helps you respond effectively in unsafe situations. A safety plan might include: knowing your boundaries and being prepared to state them; having go-to assertive phrases ready ('I need to leave now', 'That makes me uncomfortable'); identifying exit strategies (knowing where doors are, having phone charged); having your safety network contacts accessible; and knowing services you can contact. Rehearsing responses through mental practice or role-play makes them more automatic in stressful situations.

contentSections.title: Situational Awareness
contentSections.content: Situational awareness means staying alert to your environment and potential risks. This includes: noting who is around you and how they're behaving; being aware of exits and safe places; noticing changes in situations or atmospheres; trusting your instincts when something feels off; and limiting distractions (like headphones) in unfamiliar or potentially unsafe settings. Situational awareness isn't about being paranoid - it's about having information to make safe choices and respond quickly if needed.

contentSections.title: Responding and Disclosing
contentSections.content: When unsafe situations occur, response options depend on the situation. De-escalation (staying calm, not arguing, giving the person space) may help in confrontational situations. Creating distance and seeking help is often the safest option. After an unsafe situation, disclosure to a trusted adult is important even if you're unsure or it happened a while ago. When disclosing, find someone you trust, tell them what happened as clearly as you can, and remember you're not in trouble. Support services like Kids Helpline (1800 55 1800) can also help.

options.text: Brushing and styling hair
options.feedback: In the context of personal safety, grooming has a specific meaning related to manipulation.

options.text: The process by which someone builds trust with a young person in order to manipulate or abuse them
options.feedback: Correct! Grooming is a manipulative process used to gain trust and exploit young people.

options.text: Teaching someone new skills
options.feedback: In safety education, grooming refers to manipulation, not skill teaching.

options.text: Preparing for a special event
options.feedback: In this context, grooming refers to manipulative behaviour, not event preparation.

understand.question: Why does grooming often involve creating secrets between the groomer and the young person?

options.text: Because groomers like privacy
options.feedback: Secrets are a deliberate tactic to isolate, not just a preference for privacy.

options.text: To isolate the young person from their support network and make them feel like telling would be a betrayal
options.feedback: Correct! Secrecy isolates young people and creates barriers to disclosure.

options.text: Because secrets are fun
options.feedback: Unsafe secrets in grooming are harmful, not fun.

options.text: Because the young person asked for secrets
options.feedback: Groomers create secrecy as a control tactic, not at the young person's request.

apply.question: You're at a party and notice someone is making a younger student uncomfortable - standing too close, trying to get them alone, and making them drink alcohol. Apply your knowledge of warning signs - what should you do?

options.text: Mind your own business - it's not your problem
options.feedback: Bystanders can help prevent harm. This situation shows warning signs of potential harm.

options.text: Intervene by creating a distraction, checking if the younger student is okay, and telling a responsible adult
options.feedback: Correct! Intervening safely - through distraction, checking in, and getting adult help - can prevent harm.

options.text: Confront the person aggressively
options.feedback: Aggressive confrontation could escalate the situation. Safer intervention strategies are better.

options.text: Take photos to post online later
options.feedback: This doesn't help the student in the moment and could cause further harm.

analyse.question: Analyse why people who have experienced grooming often don't recognise it while it's happening. What makes grooming difficult to identify from inside the situation?

shortAnswer.rubric: Students should analyse multiple factors. Grooming is gradual, so each step seems small. The groomer appears kind and caring, creating confusion. Young people may not have learned about grooming tactics. There may be power imbalances making the young person feel they should comply. Isolation reduces outside perspectives. The young person may blame themselves. Strong responses connect these factors to show why external perspective or education helps.
successCriteria: Identifies the gradual nature of grooming
Explains how kindness from the groomer creates confusion
Discusses power imbalances or isolation as factors
Shows understanding of why education about tactics is important

evaluate.question: Evaluate the usefulness of situational awareness as a safety strategy. What are its benefits and what are its limitations?

shortAnswer.rubric: Students should evaluate both benefits and limitations. Benefits: helps identify risks early, provides information for decision-making, can prevent some unsafe situations, builds confidence. Limitations: can't prevent all harm, might cause anxiety if taken to extremes, places responsibility on potential victim rather than perpetrator, some risks are hard to anticipate. Strong responses acknowledge the value while recognising that situational awareness is one tool among many.
successCriteria: Identifies multiple benefits of situational awareness
Recognises limitations of this approach
Evaluates overall usefulness with balanced perspective
May note that it should complement other strategies

create.question: Create a personal safety plan for a scenario relevant to your life (e.g., walking home, attending a party, meeting someone you've talked to online). Include awareness strategies, planned responses, and backup plans.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students create a comprehensive safety plan for their chosen scenario. Plan should include: awareness strategies (what to look out for), prepared responses (what they would say/do), exit strategies, safety network contacts, and backup plans if first responses don't work. Plan should be realistic and personally relevant.
successCriteria: Chooses a relevant scenario
Includes awareness/prevention strategies
Plans specific responses to potential risks
Identifies safety network contacts
Includes backup or escalation options

unistructural.stem: What is one tactic that groomers often use?
unistructural.modelResponse: One tactic groomers use is giving special gifts or attention to gain trust.
unistructural.rubric: Names one grooming tactic such as gift-giving, special attention, secrecy, boundary-pushing, or isolation.

multistructural.stem: List four elements that should be included in a personal safety plan.
multistructural.modelResponse: Four elements of a personal safety plan are: 1) Awareness strategies for the situation, 2) Assertive phrases to use if needed, 3) Exit strategies and safe places to go, 4) Trusted adults or services to contact for help.
multistructural.rubric: Lists four relevant elements. May include awareness, assertive phrases, exit plans, safety network, phone access, or backup plans.

relational.stem: Explain how grooming tactics work together to control a young person and prevent disclosure.
relational.modelResponse: Grooming tactics work together in a connected way. Trust-building (kindness, gifts, attention) creates positive feelings and a sense of owing the groomer. Gradual boundary-pushing normalises inappropriate behaviour step by step, so no single step seems like a big deal. Secrecy isolates the young person from people who could help and creates a sense of special relationship. If the young person starts to resist, the groomer may use guilt ('After everything I've done for you') or threats. Together, these tactics create confusion (they seem nice but something feels wrong), isolation (no one to check with), and barriers to disclosure (shame, loyalty, fear). The young person becomes trapped by multiple interlocking controls.
relational.rubric: Explains how multiple tactics work together. Shows understanding of how tactics reinforce each other. Identifies how tactics create barriers to seeking help. Demonstrates sophisticated analysis of the grooming process.

extendedAbstract.stem: Consider why education about personal safety and grooming is important not just for potential victims but for all young people and adults. How might widespread understanding reduce harm?
extendedAbstract.modelResponse: Education for everyone reduces harm in multiple ways. For potential victims: knowledge helps them recognise warning signs early and know it's not their fault. For peers/bystanders: they can recognise when a friend is being targeted and intervene or encourage disclosure. For potential perpetrators: some inappropriate behaviour comes from not understanding boundaries; education clarifies expectations. For adults: they can better protect young people, create safer environments, and respond appropriately when concerns are raised. For society: open conversation reduces stigma around disclosure, removes the power of secrecy that groomers rely on, and creates collective vigilance. When everyone understands these dynamics, protective networks are stronger, concerning behaviour is more likely to be challenged, and young people are more likely to be believed and supported if they disclose.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Identifies benefits for multiple groups. Explains how widespread knowledge strengthens protection. Shows understanding of how community awareness reduces groomer power. Demonstrates sophisticated systems thinking about prevention.

reflectionQuestions: How has learning about grooming changed how you think about safety?
What aspects of safety planning do you want to develop further?
How might you support a friend who disclosed an unsafe situation to you?
selfAssessment: I can analyse situations for safety risks and appropriate responses
I can plan and practise protective behaviours
I understand grooming tactics and can recognise them
studentReflection.connectionToLife: Understanding protective behaviours and recognising manipulation helps you navigate relationships and situations safely. These skills are valuable in personal relationships, work, and community life.

D.title: Personal Safety and Protective Behaviours - Advanced

learningIntentions: I am learning to analyse factors that create vulnerabilities and how they can be addressed
I am learning to evaluate child protection systems and their effectiveness

I can evaluate the effectiveness of child protection approaches

Conditions that help protect people from harm
The organisations, policies, and processes designed to protect children from harm
Legal requirement for certain professionals to report suspected child abuse
An approach that recognises the impact of trauma and aims not to re-traumatise

contentSections.title: Understanding Vulnerability and Protective Factors
contentSections.content: Some factors increase vulnerability to harm while others provide protection. Vulnerability factors might include: isolation, family instability, low self-esteem, lack of safety education, disability, marginalisation, or previous abuse. Protective factors include: strong relationships with trusted adults, knowledge about safety, healthy self-esteem, supportive peer networks, and access to help services. Importantly, having vulnerability factors doesn't mean harm is inevitable or the person's fault. Understanding these factors helps target prevention and support where most needed.

contentSections.title: Child Protection Systems
contentSections.content: Societies have formal systems to protect children. These include: mandatory reporting laws requiring professionals to report suspected abuse; child protection services that investigate concerns; police who respond to criminal matters; and the courts. Informal systems include: schools, community organisations, and family networks. These systems have strengths (formal processes, accountability) and challenges (under-resourcing, not always child-centred, can be difficult to navigate). Understanding both helps identify how systems can be improved.

contentSections.title: Creating Child-Safe Organisations
contentSections.content: The Royal Commission into Institutional Responses to Child Sexual Abuse identified elements of child-safe organisations. These include: child safety embedded in leadership and governance; cultures that value children; clear codes of conduct; robust human resources practices (screening, supervision); responsive complaints processes; child-focused policies; children participating in decisions affecting them; and processes reviewed regularly. Young people can advocate for these elements in organisations they're part of - schools, sports clubs, community groups.

contentSections.title: Bystander Intervention and Advocacy
contentSections.content: Bystanders can prevent and respond to harm through intervention. The '5Ds' framework offers options: Direct (step in directly), Distract (create a diversion), Delegate (get someone else to help), Delay (check in after), Document (record for evidence if safe). Broader advocacy involves: speaking up about safety issues, supporting friends who disclose, pushing for better policies in organisations, and contributing to cultural change that doesn't tolerate harm. Young people's voices are powerful in advocating for safer communities.

analyse.question: Analyse why institutional abuse (in schools, churches, sports clubs) was often not addressed for so long in Australia.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students should analyse multiple factors. These may include: power imbalances between institutions and victims, reputation protection by institutions, inadequate reporting systems, failure to believe children, lack of understanding about abuse, cultures of silence, inadequate external oversight, and failure to share information between institutions. Strong responses connect factors to show how they reinforced each other.
successCriteria: Identifies multiple factors contributing to institutional failures
Analyses power dynamics between institutions and victims
Discusses cultural factors that enabled silence
Shows understanding of systemic rather than just individual failures

evaluate.question: Evaluate the effectiveness of mandatory reporting as a child protection strategy. What are its strengths and limitations?

shortAnswer.rubric: Students should evaluate both sides. Strengths: creates legal obligation, increases reports, provides accountability, covers key professionals. Limitations: only works if professionals recognise abuse, can lead to over-reporting of some communities, investigation doesn't guarantee protection, some professions not covered, doesn't address prevention. Strong responses consider whether mandatory reporting alone is sufficient.
successCriteria: Identifies multiple strengths of mandatory reporting
Recognises limitations of the approach
Considers the place of mandatory reporting within broader child protection
Makes reasoned evaluative judgments

create.question: Design an advocacy campaign to make organisations in your community more child-safe. Include your goals, key messages, target audiences, and proposed actions.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students design a comprehensive advocacy campaign. Should include: specific goals (what changes are sought), evidence-based key messages, identified target audiences (organisations, parents, young people), and practical action strategies. Campaign should be realistic and demonstrate understanding of what makes organisations child-safe.

Develops evidence-based key messages

unistructural.stem: Name one element of a child-safe organisation.
unistructural.modelResponse: One element is having clear codes of conduct for adult-child interactions.
unistructural.rubric: Names one relevant element such as codes of conduct, complaints processes, screening, supervision, or child participation.

multistructural.stem: List four vulnerability factors that might increase a young person's risk of experiencing harm.
multistructural.modelResponse: Four vulnerability factors are: 1) Social isolation from peers and family, 2) Low self-esteem, 3) Lack of education about safety and boundaries, 4) Previous experiences of abuse.
multistructural.rubric: Lists four relevant vulnerability factors. May include isolation, family instability, low self-esteem, lack of safety education, disability, marginalisation, or previous abuse.

relational.stem: Explain how protective factors can counteract vulnerability factors to reduce risk.
relational.modelResponse: Protective factors can counteract vulnerabilities in several connected ways. Strong relationships with trusted adults provide supervision and someone to confide in, counteracting isolation. Safety education gives knowledge and language to recognise and report concerning behaviour, counteracting lack of awareness. Healthy self-esteem helps young people recognise their worth and right to safety, counteracting low self-esteem that groomers exploit. Supportive peer networks mean friends can notice warning signs and encourage disclosure. These protective factors don't eliminate vulnerability factors, but they create buffers and resources that reduce risk and improve outcomes.
relational.rubric: Explains how specific protective factors relate to specific vulnerabilities. Shows understanding of the buffering effect. Demonstrates how factors work together rather than just listing them separately.

extendedAbstract.stem: Consider how a truly prevention-focused approach to child safety would differ from the current largely reactive system. What would need to change at individual, community, and societal levels?
extendedAbstract.modelResponse: A prevention-focused approach would represent a fundamental shift. At the individual level: universal safety education from early childhood, building protective factors like self-esteem and help-seeking skills, and education about healthy relationships. At community level: child-safe practices embedded in all organisations, training for all adults who work with children, community cultures that prioritise children's voices, and strong informal support networks. At societal level: addressing root causes of vulnerability (poverty, inequality, isolation), adequate investment in prevention programs, media that doesn't normalise harm, and systems that value children's rights. The shift required is from waiting for abuse to occur and responding, to creating conditions where abuse is less likely and more quickly addressed when it does occur. This requires seeing child safety as everyone's responsibility and investing accordingly.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Identifies changes needed at multiple levels. Distinguishes prevention from reaction clearly. Proposes meaningful systemic changes. Shows sophisticated understanding of what would be required for a prevention-focused approach.

contentSections.title: Ecological Understanding of Child Safety
contentSections.content: The ecological model understands child safety through multiple layers of influence. Individual factors include age, temperament, disability, and prior experiences. Relationship factors include family dynamics, peer relationships, and connection to trusted adults. Community factors include neighbourhood safety, school climate, and availability of services. Societal factors include cultural norms, policies, and economic conditions. Research shows that abuse is not caused by any single factor but by interactions across these levels. Effective prevention therefore requires strategies at multiple levels, from individual education to societal change.

contentSections.title: Research on Prevention
contentSections.content: Research evidence supports several prevention approaches. Universal safety education (for all children) builds knowledge and help-seeking skills. Parenting programs can strengthen family protective factors. Bystander programs increase community intervention. Organisational policies and training reduce institutional risk. Economic support for families addresses poverty as a risk factor. Public awareness campaigns can shift cultural norms. Research also shows what doesn't work: approaches that focus only on 'stranger danger' miss the reality that most abuse is by known people; fear-based approaches may reduce disclosure. Effective prevention is multi-faceted, evidence-based, and sustained.

contentSections.title: International Approaches and Ethics
contentSections.content: Countries take different approaches to child protection. Some emphasise state intervention (child protection orientation), while others prioritise family support (family service orientation). Nordic countries often combine universal services with targeted support. The UN Convention on the Rights of the Child provides a rights-based framework that most countries have ratified. Ethical considerations in child protection include: balancing protection with privacy, respecting cultural diversity while upholding universal rights, involving children in decisions about their lives, and ensuring systems don't retraumatise those seeking help.

contentSections.title: Emerging Challenges and Innovations
contentSections.content: Emerging challenges include: online-facilitated abuse requiring new prevention and response approaches; recognition of complex trauma requiring trauma-informed systems; growing understanding of harmful sexual behaviours by children and young people requiring therapeutic rather than purely punitive responses; and need to address abuse in contexts previously overlooked. Innovations include: technology for prevention education and disclosure; trauma-informed approaches throughout systems; participation of people with lived experience in designing responses; and community-based prevention initiatives. Addressing these challenges requires ongoing research, adaptation, and youth involvement in solution design.

analyse.question: Analyse the ethical tensions in child protection between respecting family privacy and the state's role in protecting children from harm.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students should analyse multiple perspectives. Family privacy arguments: families have rights to raise children according to values, state intervention can be harmful, cultural considerations matter. Child protection arguments: children have independent rights, parents don't have absolute authority, some harms are unacceptable regardless of privacy, children can't protect themselves. Tensions include: where to draw intervention thresholds, how to balance cultural respect with child rights, how to make intervention helpful not harmful. Strong responses don't simply pick a side but analyse the genuine complexity.
successCriteria: Identifies legitimate interests on both sides
Analyses specific points of tension
Considers how these tensions play out in practice
Shows nuanced understanding of competing rights

evaluate.question: Evaluate the claim that 'stranger danger' education, while well-intentioned, may actually undermine child safety. What does research suggest?

shortAnswer.rubric: Students should evaluate based on evidence. Critique: most abuse is by known people, so stranger focus misses the main risk; it may make children more confused about known-person abuse; it doesn't address grooming dynamics; it may increase fear without useful skills. Counter-points: some stranger risks exist, overall awareness may be valuable. Research supports: teaching about all types of risk, focusing on behaviour not relationship, practical skills rather than fear. Strong responses weigh evidence for a reasoned evaluation.
successCriteria: Explains why stranger focus may be problematic
References what research shows about who perpetrates abuse
Evaluates with evidence-based reasoning
Considers what education approaches are more effective

create.question: Design an innovative approach to preventing online-facilitated abuse among young people. Your approach should be evidence-informed, multi-level, and address emerging challenges.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students design a comprehensive approach. Should include: evidence base (what research shows about online risks), multi-level elements (individual digital literacy, family communication, platform design, regulation), innovation (addressing emerging challenges like new platforms, encryption, AI), practical implementation considerations, and evaluation approach. Design should demonstrate understanding of online risks while being realistic and youth-centred.
successCriteria: Grounds approach in understanding of online risks
Includes interventions at multiple ecological levels
Addresses emerging challenges specifically
Demonstrates innovation while being practical
Considers evaluation of effectiveness

unistructural.stem: What is primary prevention in child protection?
unistructural.modelResponse: Primary prevention involves strategies that prevent harm from occurring in the first place.
unistructural.rubric: Correctly defines primary prevention as preventing harm before it occurs.

multistructural.stem: List four evidence-based approaches to preventing child abuse.
multistructural.modelResponse: Four evidence-based prevention approaches are: 1) Universal safety education for children, 2) Parenting programs that strengthen family factors, 3) Bystander intervention training for community members, 4) Organisational policies and training for child-safe environments.
multistructural.rubric: Lists four relevant evidence-based approaches. May include education, parenting programs, bystander training, organisational practices, economic support, or public awareness.

relational.stem: Explain how individual, relationship, community, and societal factors interact to influence child safety outcomes.
relational.modelResponse: These factors don't operate independently but interact in complex ways. Individual vulnerability (like low self-esteem) may be influenced by relationship factors (family conflict), which may be affected by community factors (lack of support services), which connect to societal factors (poverty, inequality). Similarly, protective factors reinforce each other: a child with safety education (individual) in a supportive family (relationship) in a community with good services (community) in a society that prioritises child rights (societal) has layered protection. Risk and protection cascade across levels - family stress may be caused by economic conditions, and may affect individual children. This means effective interventions can occur at any level, but comprehensive approaches addressing multiple levels are most likely to create sustained change.
relational.rubric: Explains interactions between levels rather than just listing them. Shows understanding that factors cascade and reinforce across levels. Demonstrates how this affects both risk and protection.

extendedAbstract.stem: Consider how emerging technologies like AI-generated content, end-to-end encryption, and virtual reality create new challenges for child protection. What principles should guide our response to these unknown future challenges?
extendedAbstract.modelResponse: Emerging technologies present unprecedented challenges: AI can generate realistic child abuse material; encryption protects privacy but also prevents detection; VR creates immersive environments where harm can occur. We can't predict all future technologies, so principles are essential. Key principles should include: children's rights as the priority (applying existing rights frameworks to new contexts), precautionary approach (acting on potential harms rather than waiting for proof), proportionality (balancing safety with privacy and innovation), adaptability (building systems that can respond to change), participation (including children and young people in solution design), evidence-generation (researching new harms and evaluating responses), and international cooperation (technology crosses borders). These principles provide a framework for responding to specific technologies while remaining applicable to unknown future developments.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Identifies specific challenges from emerging technologies. Proposes principles that could guide response to unknown future challenges. Demonstrates sophisticated thinking about technology governance. Shows understanding of how to create adaptable protective frameworks.
